issues.title: Voucher is not bound to U
issues.author: geonnave
issues.body:
This was previously discussed in the IETF-118, and the goal is to discuss whether it is desirable / necessary to have the voucher be bound to U.

One open question here is: how can V be sure that the Voucher received from W is bound to the sender of message_3?

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body:
In a design team meeting last Friday (Dec 1) the following comments were raised:
- the Voucher is protected by EDHOC session via the transcript hash
- there is a consideration about doing authorization before authentication, that needs to be checked

comments.author: sftcd
comments.body:
On 04/12/2023 09:42, Geovane Fedrecheski wrote:
> In a meeting last Friday (Dec 1)

What meeting was that? (Even though this is only a github comment,
it's generally good to document that kind of thing so the IETF WG
can better evaluate outcomes from such a meeting.)

Ta,
S.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: @sftcd Good question. This was a design team meeting following up on the comments from IETF 118. Geovane is holding the pen driving the work forward :-)

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: (@geonnave Maybe edit comments and make global replace "meeting" -> "design team meeting".)

issues.title: Add EAD_3 field?
issues.author: geonnave
issues.body:
After receiving message_3, V may want to check that CRED_U is bound to the voucher received from W (see #1). In this case, V would need to (1) have the voucher saved on state, and (2) it would have to dispatch a "check CRED_U against Voucher" action.

Right now, on the implementation side, dispatching any EAD-related action is done via detecting the presence of an EAD field (since the core EDHOC implementation must be agnostic of EAD items).

Thus, it may make sense to add an EAD_3 field to enable such a dispatch.

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: As discussed in the design team meeting, the next step is to think of additional scenarios where this might be needed (if any).

issues.title: Should the voucher include a scope?
issues.author: geonnave
issues.body: During the IETF-118 meeting, it was discussed whether the Voucher should include a scope. One simple alternative would be to propose an opaque "scope" field whose usage details would be left to the application.

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body:
As discussed in the last design team meeting, we do plan to include a scope field. That may involve updating the Voucher structure to be a COSE_Encrypt0, where ciphertext is the concatenation of encrypted-plaintext (empty) and the voucher MAC. The scope can then be included in the encrypted-plaintext or in the (un)protected header. 

The scope would convey information to U about V, such as capabilities of V, usage policies, etc. I think we need to think of a few concrete examples here.

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: After the merge of #11, the voucher can now include extra data, such as a scope. The actual contents that we may wish to send, however, may not be a scope as much as _assertions_ or _directives_ from W to U.

issues.title: Add error handling
issues.author: geonnave
issues.body:
The protocol should include an error handling mechanism. Below is a first sketch as well as a few considerations to be discussed:

```
W may answer Voucher Request with a Voucher Error (VERR):

VERR = (code: uint, ?info: bstr)
```

Notes:
- security: VERR should be encrypted and integrity-protected, e.g. `COSE_Encrypt0` from W to U, just like `ENC_ID` on `EAD_1`
- how to transport: 
  - W to V: the encrypted VERR is sent via the secure channel already established between both parties
  - V to U: we can possibly reuse EDHOC's error signalling (see [lake-edhoc#section-6](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-lake-edhoc-22.html#section-6)). Thus the encrypted VERR could be the content of `ERR_INFO`. Note that this might require declaring a new EDHOC `ERR_CODE`, so that `ERR_INFO` can have a content of type `bstr`.

cc @gselander @malishav

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: Solved in #9.

issues.title: Appendix or Examples section
issues.author: geonnave
issues.body:
A section with example use cases for the protocol can improve readability of the spec.

Here is a brief list of use cases that can serve as base for such section:

```
### UC1: voucher works, 1 gateway

premises:
- devices = [u1, …]
- discovered_gateways = [v1]
- W’s allowlist = v1: [u1]

scenarios:
1. device u1 tries to join via gateway v1, W accepts and replies Voucher Response

### UC2: basic error response, 1 gateway

premises:
- devices = [u1, …]
- discovered_gateways = [v1]
- W’s allowlist = v1: []

scenarios:
1. device u1 tries to join via gateway v1, W denies and replies Voucher Error

### UC3: basic error response, 5 gateways

premises:
- devices = [u1, …]
- discovered_gateways = [v1, v2, v3, v4, v5] // sorted e.g. by rssi
- W’s allowlist = v1: [], v2: [], v3: [u1], v4: [u1], v5: []

scenarios:
1. device u1 tries to join via gateway v1, W denies and replies Voucher Error
2. device u1 tries to join via gateway v2, W denies and replies Voucher Error
3. device u1 tries to join via gateway v3, W accepts and replies Voucher Response

### UC4: error includes gateway hint, 5 gateways

premises:
- devices = [u1, …]
- discovered_gateways = [v1, v2, v3, v4, v5] // sorted e.g. by rssi
- W’s allowlist = v1: [], v2: [], v3: [u1], v4: [u1], v5: []

scenarios:
1. device u1 tries to join via gateway v1, W denies and replies Voucher Error with hint = [v3, v4]
2. device u1 tries to join via gateway v3, W accepts and replies Voucher Response
```

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Looks good to me. I think UC1 & UC4 (scenario 1) could be sufficient, perhaps start with them?

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: Addressed in #10

issues.title: Device enrollment in the presence of many Vs
issues.author: geonnave
issues.body:
The access policies in W may contain a mapping of which Us are authorized to join via which Vs, e.g. `{v1: [u1, u2], v2: [u3]}`. In this case, if a device detects many Vs in its vicinity, it may have to try to exhaustively try to enroll via different Vs until it finds the right one (see use case UC3 in issue #6).

A possible solution includes sharing more information between V and W, so that this process can be sped up. Here is an initial sketch of how it could look like:

```
# Enrollment hints
This section defines optional fields with the purpose of improving protocol scalability, aiming to reduce battery usage and enrollment delay.
The main use case is when several potential gateways (V) are detected by U's radio, which can lead to U trying to enroll (and failing) several times until it finds a suitable V.

## Domain Authenticator hints
In case W denies the enrollment of U to a given V, a list of Domain Authenticator hints (v_hints) can be sent from W to U.
The hint is optional and is sent as part of an error message.
It consists of a list of application-defined identifiers of V (e.g. MAC addresses, SSIDs, PAN IDs, etc.), as defined below:

v_hints = [ 1* bstr ]

## Device hints
U may send a Device hint (u_hint) so that it can help W to select which Vs to include in v_hints.
This can be useful in large scale scenarios with many gateways (V).
The hint is an optional field in EAD_1, and it must be encrypted.
The hint itself is application dependent, and can contain GPS coordinates, application-specific tags, the list of Vs detected by U, or other relevant information.
It is defined as follows:

u_hint: [ 1* bstr ]
```

Notes:
- related to #5, as `v_hint` would be carried in the Voucher Error message
- all hints should be encrypted and integrity-protected, e.g., via `COSE_Encrypt0`

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: Solved in #13

issues.title: Clarifications on the usage of OPAQUE_INFO
issues.author: geonnave
issues.body:
> If could be good to clarify that “OPAQUE_INFO” is opaque when viewed as information element in EDHOC. It is opaque to V but the application in U and W can read the contents.

^ by @gselander in [PR 13](https://github.com/lake-wg/authz/pull/13#issuecomment-1976265705).

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: Solved in #18

issues.title: Explain error response in the context of the VREQ/VRES protocol
issues.author: geonnave
issues.body:
See [previous comment](https://github.com/lake-wg/authz/pull/13#issuecomment-1976281759) by @gselander:

```
One more comment:

"W generates error_content and transfers it to V via the secure connection."

We should explain how this message is part of the VREQ/VRES protocol. This is not necessary an error from the point of view of that protocol. If we don't have a quick fix, make a separate issue.

Edit: For example, add a flag in VRES

Voucher_Response = [
message_1: bstr,
flag: int,
response: bstr,
? opaque_state: bstr
]

flag = -1 is used with response = Voucher. In case of reject, then (flag, response) = error_content.

(or other preferred construction)

Edit: Or reserve REJECT_TYPE = 0 for the no reject case. The flag/ REJECT_TYPE thus becomes a status code for the VREQ/VRES protocol. Maybe rename "REJECT_TYPE" accordingly. Or leave out for this update.
```

issues.title: authz with U as R and V as I
issues.author: chrysn
issues.body:
(Moved from https://github.com/EricssonResearch/ace-ake-authz/issues/27)

Processing some deployment scenarios (involving CoAP-over-GATT), I've found that sometimes the roles of I and R would be reversed.

Apart from the aspect of vulnerable-identities, is there anything fundamentally keeping the ENC_U_INFO from being in message 2, and the voucher from being in message 3? The credential database lookup would then be against ID_CRED_R, but that'd be the same interface as for ID_CRED_I.

Let's not sink too much time into this if it turns out to be complicated -- I'm not sure whether running EDHOC over CoAP in reverse flow may not be the better choice in this situation anyway, but if this has ever been contemplated in other places, this issue might be a good spot to spool ideas.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
I think that we have made some significant optimizations assuming U as I.
I think that there are different optimizations that occur if V is I.
CoAP-over-GATT probably does not need a discovery process whereby V discovers a U that it should initiate to.

V as I has many advantages when it comes to managing bandwidth.

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body: Indeed the flow in the GATT case would be that U sends a beacon that contains a 32bit hash of LOC_W, so V would likely already have a good idea of what W would be (given that in a list of peered W, this likely only matches 1 or at most 3) – so the first EAD would only contain LOC_W for confirmation (or maybe not at all).

pulls.title: Implementation notes
pulls.author: geonnave
pulls.body: There are 3 clarifications in separate commits. I am not totally sure if the consideration about credentials by value should be in the introduction, but I wanted them to be upfront in the document since it is a requirement to EDHOC implementations who wish to support this.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Looks good, I made some editorial changes.

(For some reason editor's copy won't update, don't understand why.)

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: @gselander thank you. The problem was a missing reference declaration, and is now fixed.

pulls.title: Add error section
pulls.author: geonnave
pulls.body: Adding an error handling section. Work in progress.

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: Note that the second example (equivalent to UC4 in #6) does not include the `hint`, as it is not specified yet. It can be added back once that is done.

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: @gselander I added more details to the examples, do you want to take a look?

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
Looks good, but I didn't understand this:

> the access policy in W specifies, via a list of ID_U, that device u1 can enroll via any domain authenticator, i.e., the list is: \[14\]

How can I understand that the list has this format?

comments.author: gselander
geonnave
comments.body:
> How can I understand that the list has this format?

My goal is just to provide an example of how the access policy could look like at W, while its exact format is out of scope (it is up to the authorization mechanism to define that).

Maybe I could change it to `e.g., the access policy could look like this: [14]` (note the use of `e.g.` instead of `i.e.`) to make it clear that it is just an example.

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body:
> The brackets are confusing, but is the absence of other entries (besides 14) in the previous example an indication that there is no restriction on what gateway?

Yes, I intend for one example to have no restriction on the gateway, and another to have such restriction. The bracket notation is supposed to denote a mapping of ID_U and MAC Addresses, I can think of something else if that is not clear.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
> Yes, I intend for one example to have no restriction on the gateway, and another to have such restriction. The bracket notation is supposed to denote a mapping of ID_U and MAC Addresses, I can think of something else if that is not clear.

Yes, please change from "i.e." to "e.g.", the former gives the impression that there is something that should be understood based on something else. The examples are fine. It would be good with a common notation was used in both examples, and perhaps also the asymmetry between the first element and the following element(s), for example (14; MAC1, MAC2, ...)  and (14; ). Or (14; *).

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body:
I re-arranged the text so that there is no "expectation" on formats that are not defined. In doing so I decided to keep `i.e.`, because using `e.g.` again within the example felt redundant.

In summary, the changes are:
1. in the first example, I abstracted away the format of the policy
2. in the second one, I defined the policy format, so that I could use `i.e.` to mean a clear implication

pulls.title: Ability to transfer opaque application data
pulls.author: geonnave
pulls.body:
Addressing #3.

The idea is to use 'ciphertext' from COSE_Encrypt0, which already has a MAC (the authentication tag), with the added benefit that now it is possible for W to send encrypted opaque data to U.

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body:
Some notes:
- I am not sure `SCOPE` is the best name here. Maybe `OPAQUE_DATA` or similar (open to ideas).
- I don't know if there is a rule for naming things like `K_2` and `info_label`, so I just incremented them from the values already in the draft.

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body:
Discussed in the design team meeting:

```
# from U to W:
now: plaintext = ID_U
desired: plaintext =

ENC_U_INFO = (
  ID_U: bstr
  ?opaque_info: bstr
    e.g. available_networks, e.g. mac address (previously u_hints)
)

# from W to U:
ENC_W_INFO = (
  ?opaque_info: bstr
    e.g. selected/proposed_networks, e.g. mac address (previously v_hints)
)
```

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body:
Just to update on the above, what we really want is to enable transmission of an optional OPAQUE_INFO in the three cases below:

```
1. from U to W, within EAD_1 / Voucher_Info
ENC_U_INFO = (
  ID_U: bstr
  ?OPAQUE_INFO: bstr
    e.g. available_networks, e.g. mac address (previously u_hints)
)

2. from W to U, within EAD_2 / Voucher
plaintext of Voucher = (
  ?OPAQUE_INFO: bstr
    e.g. selected/proposed_networks, e.g. mac address (previously v_hints)
)

(note that in this case the MAC, which was originally the full content of the Voucher, will be the authentication tag generated during encryption)

3. from W to U, within Error message
plaintext of REJECT_INFO = (
    ?OPAQUE_INFO:            bstr,
)
```

In this PR, cases 1 and 2 are addressed (I am updating its title).
Case 3 is being handled in PR #9, and will be updated once this one is settled, as it is now establishing some new terminology.

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: @gselander I added an example of what could go in the voucher on commit [893d156](https://github.com/lake-wg/authz/pull/11/commits/893d156d4bfdea0a1a260822caf63163aa49a783). Could you please take a look?

pulls.title: Update draft name and URLs
pulls.author: geonnave
pulls.body:
Similar to #8. This also updates the filename to match the working group draft name.

Not sure how to update the diff URL though.

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: Closing as it was solved in commits https://github.com/lake-wg/authz/commit/085fd96bce160938420a6aaadef62876539d0d8f and https://github.com/lake-wg/authz/commit/72a75a10e582c553ff1600d902d66a7346095f6b

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
I read through the changes, some minor comments: 

* If could be good to clarify that “OPAQUE_INFO” is opaque when viewed as information element in EDHOC. It is opaque to V but the application in U and W can read the contents.
* “The hint is an optional field in EAD_1, and it must be encrypted.”
Clarify that u_hint is included in OPAQUE_INFO.
* Similarly, clarify that v_hint in included in REJECT_INFO
* Nit: All words in upper case in titles: "Enrollment hints"->"Enrollment Hints", etc.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body:
One more comment: 

"W generates error_content and transfers it to V via the secure connection."

We should explain how this message is part of the VREQ/VRES protocol. This is not necessary an error from the point of view of that protocol. If we don't have a quick fix, make a separate issue.

Edit: For example, add a flag in VRES

Voucher_Response = [
    message_1:      bstr,
    flag:               int,
    response:        bstr,
    ? opaque_state: bstr
]

flag = -1 is used with response = Voucher.  In case of reject, then (flag, response) = error_content.

(or other preferred construction)

Edit: Or reserve REJECT_TYPE = 0 for the no reject case. The flag/ REJECT_TYPE thus becomes a status code for the VREQ/VRES protocol. Maybe rename "REJECT_TYPE" accordingly. Or leave out for this update.

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body:
Thank you @chrysn and @gselander for your comments.

Note that the reviewed text included more commits than just the hints. I just rebased it from master to include just the hints' update.

Finally, @gselander I just addressed the comments that applied to the hints section. Will address the remaining ones in a separate issue.

comments.author: gselander
comments.body: Thanks @geonnave, ff0d6c3 looks good.

reviews.author: chrysn
reviews.body: The voucher details are something I care about, and that text looks good to me.

pulls.title: CoJP examples: Don't send extra Content-Format
pulls.author: chrysn
pulls.body:
Sending these is optional in oscore-edhoc, and given there is a SHALL in the text, this needlessly increases the verbosity over the air.

(I'm tempted to state something similar about the CON in message 1, especially with regard to RFC9031's text on join proxies, but at least that's more complicated, and removing content-format is easy).

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: @malishav I think you have more context on the impact of this change, could you please take a look?

comments.author: geonnave
comments.body: Thank you for your contribution @chrysn!

reviews.author: malishav
reviews.body: I believe @chrysn is right. There is a SHALL in our text on how to transport the message but we include Content-Format there, although it is optionally transported (media-type can be inferred from the URI) according to draft-ietf-core-oscore-edhoc. I think the PR is OK to be merged.
